reviewText:
I love the King's Bounty games, I really do.
But King's Bounty: Legions just doesn't feel right. All of the elements that made the previous games interesting were removed or tweaked to provide the most bland and generic experience possible to the player.

In this game, there is no specialisation, you can spend your gold on marginal upgrades for units and spells, but cost scaling and level requirements for these upgrades is made in such a way that you can't just decide to dump all your gold into spells and rely on them. Especially since you can't learn spells, you have no mana, you have to buy scrolls, every time you use a spell you need to use a scroll.

When it comes to army building, there isn't much to it unless you are willing to pay, you have access to some basic units from shops, and a few advanced units as quest rewards, but only enough to show you what these units can do and encourage you to purchase more at the real money shop. You just don't get the satisfaction of doing your best with limited resources like you did in the previous games, especially since morale mechanics and most of the units special effects were removed.

Finally,  you don't have to select your battles like in the previous games, here you simply progress from one area to another with the ability to grind when you feel you aren't strong enough to take on the next challenge.

The only thing that's left from the previous games is the turn-based gameplay, which just isn't enough to hold the game together without the strategic elements that the previous games had.

A good attempt at a free low budget multiplayer spin off of the king's bounty genre, but single player experience is very disappointing.

As a fan of the King's bounty series, this seemed like a great idea - and the inital hours of free-to-play games usually are (in order to draw you in) - but the game quickly looses pace, and annoying, trying to lure you into spending money in order to speed up the ever increasingly grinding rate of play.

Would much rather spend money up front to pay for a game. The idea of people using money to gain advantage over other players instead of using skill is abhorrent and I refuse to entertain it.

reviewText:
Having played the original for Sega Genesis, I had to try this game. Unfortunately, I was disappointed. The music wasn't bad, though not as catchy as the original, IMO. The gameplay is where the largest difference was. There is hardly a connection to the original, other than unit type and battle similarities.

The methods by which troops are recruited are totally different. The basic units could be hired at the home castle, but exotic units would have to be hired from their lairs in the unexplored wilderness. Part of the challenge and fun was finding some of the more rare units during your travels. In fact, there is no exploring at all in the new game. You must defeat a predetermined number of groups of enemies before being able to advance to the next town. The new game is repetitive and slow in its progression. The battles lack the save level of dynamics and difficulty of the original. Although there are some character upgrades (equipment, etc.), you are limited to one character. The original offered 3 different characters with different strengths (income and rank, leadership, and magic).

Overall, there was more freedom in the original, and everything, from the music to the exploration and battles, was more interesting. The new game lacks challenge and is very tedious. The game name King's Bounty" shouldn't be associated with this game."

You will need a lot of friends to help you unlock the wanted missions. Those missions will give you free units. Daily quests will also give you free units. I believe you should have everything upgraded eventually if you are patiently enough. That should take 3 years maybe. This is a true long grind. Play this when you want to kill time.

reviewText:
Originally featured on Kongregate.com, King's Bounty Legions borrows the popular working formula from the original King's Bounty series.

To accomodate casual player and to become a MMO, NivalPublishing watered down the brutality of the original series. Instead of loosing troops and lose the ability to hire them again, the hire pool refreshes every daily. Immortal and Legendary units are rehirable at a price as they are unavaliable to replanish on the map.

Unlike other MMOs on the market which requires a lot of attention to maintain a well equipted account, Legions tries to accomodate gamers who are able to commit less than an hour a day by introducing dailies which can be completed in minutes and a patrol mode.

In patrol mode, the player leaves the avatar at a location and the AI does battles over time. The player can sustain losses in this mode. However, in a reasonable location, a positive income together with additional rewards makes Legions a game for busy people.

Legions demostrates great promise with a good compromise between free and paid gamers. However, increasingly powerful and pricey units found on the Royal Shop (the Cash Shop on King's Bounty: Legions) greatly tilts the favor towards paid gamers in the PVP arena. (*I am trying to remember whether PVP yields any unique rewards. If it does, the game would greatly favor paying customers with a fat wallet).

Fortunately, the the game redeems itself by introducing a Raid feature which pits players against various other player's teams and everything boils down to defeating the AI which controls them.

What further irks me is the inability to transfer progression between different platforms. In my case, my progress from Kongregate to Steam.

Still, this game is a good introduction for players who are undecided on purchasing the original King's Bounty series, a new to turn based role playing game or an online world to test their skills against other like minded gamers.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Better than expected. Not a waste of time.

Basically, this is a Facebook game. At least I think it's an import from FB, since you can share to your wall and it has that terrible hand-holding tutorial for the first 10 mins of gameplay. Try to power through the big dumb CLICK HERE YOU IDIOT buttons and when the game opens up a bit more it's very fun.

It has Might and Magic/King's Bounty style combat, but none of the overworld parts (Which I never really cared for a ton anyway). Units are stacked and your attacks chew through each individual guy's HP until you kill the whole stack. The focus on Combat and army building over the larger scale city building and adventuring is welcome for me, others may not like that. It reminds me of playing a somewhat obscure Playstation 2 game, Gladius, since it's fight after fight with a bit of crafting and a quest between each one.

I'd say give it a try, but be careful of microtransactions. Not sure how good the PvP is yet, or if there's pay-to-win, but I wouldn't be surprised. It's a fun, cut down King's Bounty experience though.

reviewText:
Back in 1991 I played a game named “Kings Bounty”. Little did I know at the time, that this simple game would grow and gain such a following in the modern computer world. Well, now we have a new version of the game, and it is all grown up. “Kings Bounty Legions”.

Kings Bounty was not much to look at, but the game play was awesome. I spent hours playing it and could not get enough. What is so unbelievable is that after 22 years, the game is still growing and going strong.

The new Kings Bounty Legions is visually stunning, and the game play, better. In this game, you can grow an army, do quests, get rewards, and once again grow your army. What makes this game so different is the 3D quality of the battle scenes, and the ease of play.  There is no base building or taking over cities in this game, so it plays more like Kings Bounty series of games than Heroes of Might and Magic for those who are familiar with the two after they split into separate series of games.  So the game does consist of a lot of one battle after another, and the duel match up is flawed in that it will often throw you against opponents who are way too high of a level with little to no chance of you beating them, so there could be some better algorithm about dueling and the game not forcing you to battle opponents higher than 3 or 4 levels than you where you have no chance of winning, but other than that it is a pretty fun game and if you liked playing Kings Bounty Armored Princess or Kings Bounty The Legend you will likely find the game enjoyable.

You can fight against random foes, or engage in PVP battles. Now, on Facebook, this is not something new, but this game does something many of the other’s do not. It gives you more choices, more control, and it does it like you would expect a paid, installed, game to do.

For an internet-based game, the action and play is better than anything I have ever played online. Kings Bounty legions uses the Unity 3D Technology, which gives it the edge that makes this game so much better than the competition.

reviewText:
King’s Bounty: Legions

King’s Bounty has a long and prestigious history in PC gaming. Some would even say a storied history. Well, not many of us would say that. But I might. It is a fairly well known strategy RPG with a pedigree reaching back to the dawn of PC gaming. In recent years, developer Nival Interactive has released a few new games in the series to largely rave reviews. They have always stuck to their guns and kept the games difficult and deep, rather than caving to the recent revolution in simplifying modern gaming. Now they have released their newest title, King’s Bounty: Legions. A free-to-play game tied inextricably to the all-consuming monster that is Facebook. Does this mean Nival has finally sold out and simplified the series? Or is there a legitimate game hidden in here that they have simply chosen to release under a new kind of business plan? In all honesty, the end result is a bit of a mixed bag.

To its credit, King’s Bounty: Legions does not have “energy” or whatever the equivalent resource is that most Facebook games use to limit playtime unless you purchase more. You can play as long as you like each sitting without having to worry about some arbitrary limitation holding you back for a few hours while it recharges. The main barrier to entry is simply time consumption. You are of course able to purchase all kinds of gameplay benefits with cash which do give you distinct advantages, such as “auras” that grant you increased experience and gold gain, or more units to use in combat. There are many other options as well. These are all the typical trappings of a free-to-play game. Multiple currencies include gold, gained in game, and gems, purchased with real money. Gold can be used to resurrect units lost in battle and purchase additional units to fill your army as well as buy spells and items. Gems are used for upgrading your troops, spells, and all manner of additional things.

As far as the gameplay goes, it is a moderately simplified version of a typical King’s Bounty game. There is no more over-world exploration component, you now have a very simplified ‘world map’ that you simply choose a destination on to move your static player character icon. You move from icon to icon, collecting and completing simple quests to kill a number of each creature or defeat a specific army. All depth and strategy has, disappointingly, been thrown out of the world map aspect of the game.

So how about combat? Well, it is once again a mixed bag. Spells have been all but removed, and turned into single use items you have to purchase with gold and are not affected in any way by character development. Which itself is also entirely missing from the game. Gone are the days of choosing skills and the specialization of your character to fit with your own play style. Combat is dumbed down to the larger stack wins, with many units having had skills simply thrown out and replaced with nothing. It is largely a disappointment and pales in comparison to previous games in the illustrious King’s Bounty history.

Having said these things it is only fair to say that, as a Facebook game, King’s Bounty: Legions does succeed at what it aims to be. A relatively simple time sink to rake in some capital. It does have obnoxious pop-ups that constantly tell you to “Share X with your friend!”, and insipid purchases to boost you ahead in the game, yes. But it also doesn’t force the purchases down your throat or force you to spend time waiting in order to play again. For fans of free-to-play Facebook games, King’s Bounty: Legions may very well be appealing. Nival Interactive has done a fairly respectable job of transforming the game into a social title, and will likely make large sums of cash as a result. For those of us who don’t give a flying rat’s caboose about Facebook, though, it is a definitive pass. Play an older title in the series instead, and be much happier for it. With any luck, the boys over at Nival will use some of the incoming cash flow to build us a real sequel in the days to come. One that lives up to the great talents they have demonstrated so many times in the past.
